task.title: Step 1 of 2. Write text to user selection
task.description: The Document object exposes a method to write to the user's current selection in a document or spreadsheet. To do that, the Document object provides the setSelectedDataAsync method. The following example uses this method to write text into the spreadsheet (see later tutorials to learn how to write matrix and table data structures). The callback function returns an object containing the status of the performed operation.

task.title: Step 2 of 2. Read text from user selection
task.description: The Document object also exposes the getSelectedDataAsync method to read from the user's current selection in a document or spreadsheet. The following example uses this method to read text from the spreadsheet by specifying the coercionType parameter as CoercionType.Text. You can also use the getSelectedDataAsync method to read range (matrix) and table data in Excel and Word, specifying either of those data types as the coercionType parameter of the method. The callback function returns an object containing the data currently selected by the user, which can use the asyncResult.value property to access the selected data.

task.title: Step 1 of 2. Write a range (matrix) to user selection
task.description: The following example uses the setSelectedDataAsync method to write a matrix data structure, which is a range of cells, into the current selection in the spreadsheet. To do so, pass an array of arrays that contains the data to write to the setSelectedAsync method as the data parameter. Be aware that a matrix can only be written into the spreadsheet if no other data in the surrounding cells will be overwritten. The callback function returns an object containing the status of the performed operation.

task.title: Step 2 of 2. Read range (matrix) from user selection
task.description: The following example uses the getSelectedDataAsync method to read the currently selected range of cells. To specify that the selection is read as a range of cells, specify the coerctionType parameter as CoercionType.Matrix. The callback function returns an object containing the data currently selected by the user, which can use the asyncResult.value property to access the data.

task.title: Step 1 of 2. Write a table to user selection
task.description: The following example uses the setSelectedDataAsync method to write a table into the current selection in the spreadsheet. The table data type is represented by the TableData object. We first instantiate the object, add sample headers and rows and then pass it as the data parameter to the method. Be aware that a table can only be written into the spreadsheet if no other data in the surrounding cells will be overwritten. The callback function returns an object containing the status of the performed operation.

task.title: Step 2 of 2. Read a table from user selection
task.description: The following example uses the getSelectedDataAsync method to read the currently selected table. The CoercionType.Table parameter specifies the expected data type. The callback function returns an object containing the data currently selected by the user, which can be accessed by the asyncResult.value property.

scenario.title: Update a Row in a Table

task.title: Step 1 of 3. Write a table to user selection
task.description: The first step in this tutorial is to write the sample table to work with. As shown in previous tutorials, the setSelectedDataAsync method can be used to write the data.

task.title: Step 2 of 3. Bind to the table
task.description: The next step is to bind to the table. Unlike the basic writing and reading methods, binding to a region in a document establishes a link between that region and the add-in that can be referenced later on. After a Binding object is created, you can access it at any time, read and write data to the region of the document associated with it, and handle selection and data change events. This example demonstrates binding to the user’s current selection using the addFromSelectionAsync method. Be aware that bindings can also be created based on selection from a prompt (Excel only), and from existing named items in the document and spreadsheet. The example also shows how a binding ID can be specified (‘MyTableBinding’) when you create the binding. The binding ID can then be used to retrieve the binding. The callback function returns an asyncResult object containing the binding, which can be accessed using the asyncResult.value property.

task.title: Step 3 of 3. Update row in the binding
task.description: Now we can use the binding object created in the previous step to update the table content. The example shows how to retrieve the table binding based on its ID using the Office.select selector method and then calls the setDataAsync method to write data into the binding object, which will be reflected in the table associated with the binding. First, a TableData object containing one row, is created. The TableData object is then passed as the data parameter to the method along with a startRow parameter value to indicate the position in the table to replace with the supplied table. Be aware that the shape of the table used to update the binding must match the shape of the updated table in terms of the number of columns and rows. The callback function returns an asyncResult object containing the status of the performed operation.

task.title: Extra Credit: Add Column to the table
task.description: In addition to updating existing data in the table, the table binding object can be used to add new columns and rows. The example shows how to retrieve the table binding based on its ID using the getById method exposed by the Bindings object. First, a TableData object containing a header and one column is created. Once the binding object is retrieved, the new table is passed as the data parameter to the addColumnsAsync method. Be aware, that just like updating table data, adding columns and rows requires that the shape of object added to the table matches the shape of the table (in this example, the new column created has the same number of rows as the table). The callback function returns an asyncResult object containing the status of the performed operation. Office.select selector method and then calls the setDataAsync method to write data into the binding object, which will reflect in the table.

task.title: Step 1 of 3. Write a range to user selection
task.description: The first step in this tutorial is to write a sample range of cells (matrix) into the document. As shown in previous tutorials, the setSelectedDataAsync method can be used to write the data.

task.title: Step 2 of 3. Bind to range
task.description: The next step is to bind to the range (matrix). Binding to a region in a document establishes a link between that region and the add-in that can be referenced later on. After a Binding object is created, you can retrieve it at any time, read and write data to the region of the document associated with it, and handle selection and data change events. This example demonstrates binding by displaying a prompt using the addFromPromptAsync method, which prompts the user to make a selection in the document and binds to that selection. Be aware that bindings can also be created based on current user selection (without displaying a prompt) and from existing named items in the document or spreadsheet. The example also shows how a binding ID can be specified when you create the binding. The binding ID, 'MyMatrixBinding', can then be used to retrieve the binding. The callback function returns an asyncResult object containing the binding object, which can be accessed by using the asyncResult.value property.

task.title: Step 3 of 3. Detect selection changes
task.description: After binding to the matrix, the next step is to detect when a user changes selection in that range and then read the selected cell coordinates. This can be done by adding an event handler function to the binding to detect selection change events. Once the event is triggered, the event handler function, onBindingSelectionChanged(), is called and gets data from the binding using the Binding.getDataAsync method. By default, the getDataAsync method returns all the data contained in a text, matrix, or table binding. However, it is possible to get a partial set of the data by specifying the startRow, startColumn, rowCount and columnCount parameters of the method. The data is then returned by the asyncResult object and can be accessed through the value property.

task.title: Step 1 of 3. Set Setting
task.description: The Settings object makes it possible to store data associated with the user or the app. The data is saved in the document file and can be retrieved at any point later. Be aware that settings are saved per document and not per add-in, so it's only possible to retrieve settings saved in the current document. This is very useful for caching data specific to the add-in state for the current document. This example shows how to use the Settings.set method to store a key value pair of strings. This setting will be made available during the entire add-in session.

task.title: Step 2 of 3. Get Settings
task.description: To get a setting previously set or saved by the add-in, use the Settings.get method.

task.title: Step 3 of 3. Save Settings
task.description: Any setting previously saved by an add-in is loaded when the document is initialized, so during the lifetime of the session you can just use the set and get methods to read and write settings. When you want to persist the settings so that they are available the next time the add-in is used with the document, use the saveAsync method.

task.title: Step 2 of 3. Register to the active view changed event

task.title: Step 3 of 3. Unregister to the active view changed event

task.description: This event will be fired whenever a new document selection is made.

task.description: This is the way to get id/index/title of selected slides, the first slide returned should be the current active slide.

task.title: Step 2 of 4. Go to a slide by id

task.description: You can go to a first/last/next/previous slide by using their keyword. This is the most useful navigation for content add-ins. Try using different keywords.

task.title: Step 4 of 4. Go to slide by index

task.title: Step 2 of 2. Navigate to table

task.description: Get the location of the document by using getFilePropertiesAsync.

task.title: Step 1 of 1. Set formatting on a table

task.title: Step 1 of 5. Get the type of the email body
task.description: Inside a mailbox item, use the body object to access the body of your email. Call body.getTypeAsync to determine the type of the email body, which is either HTML or text.

task.title: Step 2 of 5. Set message subject
task.description: When composing an email, set the message subject to a specific string using the subject.setAsync method.

task.title: Step 3 of 5. Prepend text to the email body
task.description: When composing an email, use the body object to access the body of your email. Call body.prependAsync to write the specified text at the start of the email body.

task.title: Step 4 of 5. Write text in email body
task.description: When composing an email, use the body object to access the body of your email. Call body.setSelectedDataAsync to write the specified text at the currently selected location. note that this will only write to the body of the email, not the subject line.

task.title: Step 5 of 5. Set entire email body
task.description: When composing an email, use the body.setAsync method to write the entire body of the email. This method can be used to set the body to plaintext, but it can also set HTML, as seen in the example.

task.title: Step 1 of 2. Display reply form
task.description: The Message object gives access to the current message, exposing the displayReplyForm method. The simplest way to create a reply email is to call the displayReplyForm method with a single string parameter representing the reply text.
task.code: Office.context.mailbox.item.displayReplyForm("This is my reply");

task.title: Step 2 of 2. Display reply all form
task.description: The Message object gives access to the current message, exposing the displayReplyAllForm method. The simplest way to create a reply all email is to call the displayReplyAllForm method with a single string parameter representing the reply text.
task.code: Office.context.mailbox.item.displayReplyAllForm("This is my reply ALL");

task.title: Step 1 of 3. Get available email IDs
task.description: Using Office.content.mailbox.item, retrieve the ID of the single email being read using the itemId property, and the conversation to which it belongs using the conversationId property.

task.title: Step 2 of 3. Send an email
task.description: Send an email using the Mailbox.makeEwsRequestAsync method. Specify messages to send and intended recipients. Note: Your Add-in must have ReadWriteMailbox permissions to use this method!

task.title: Step 3 of 3. Get callback token
task.description: Use the mailbox.getCallbackTokenAsync method to retrieve a token which authorizes future EWS calls. After the callback token is retrieved, it can be used for the next five minutes to make GetAttachment or GetItem requests.

task.title: Step 1 of 2. Get email subject
task.description: When in read mode, subject can be easily retrieved via the item subject property. In compose mode, use the subject.getAsync method to retrieve the subject.

task.title: Step 2 of 2. Get email body
task.description: Retrieve the entire body of an email using the body.getAsync method. Specify whether to retrieve the body in HTML or plaintext format.

task.title: Step 1 of 4. item.notificationMessages.addAsync
task.description: Use notificationMessages.addAsync to append a notification to the top of a message. Each notification message must have a unique key, plus a JSON object designating type, icon, message, and persistence of the notification. The types of notification message are progressIndicator (seen in this example), informationalMessage, and errorMessage.

task.title: Step 2 of 4. item.notificationMessages.replaceAsync
task.description: Like addAsync, notificationMessages.replaceAsync takes in a unique key and a JSON object, but rather than creating a new notification message, it replaces the current message with the designated key with the new notification message.

task.title: Step 3 of 4. item.notificationMessages.getAllAsync
task.description: To see the details of every notification linked to the current item, use the notificationMessages.getAllAsync method.

task.title: Step 4 of 4. item.notificationMessages.removeAsync
task.description: Like the add and replace methods, notificationMessages.removeAsync takes in a unique notification key. It then deletes the notification message with that key.

task.title: Step 2 of 3. Get Settings
task.description: To get a setting previously set or saved by the add-in, use the RoamingSettings.get method.

task.title: Step 3 of 3. Save Settings
task.description: RoamingSettings.set only creates or modifies a setting in the current session. When you want to persist the settings so that they are available the next time the add-in is used, use the RoamingSettings.saveAsync method.

task.title: Step 1 of 2. Save draft
task.description: Use item.saveAsync method to save the current draft. This method is only available in compose mode.

task.title: Step 2 of 2. Close draft
task.description: Use the item.Close method to close the current email draft. If there are unsaved changes, the user will be prompted to save. This method is only available in compose mode.
task.code: Office.context.mailbox.item.close();

task.title: Step 1 of 3. Read text of user selection
task.description: The ProjectDocument object exposes the getSelectedDataAsync method to read from the user's current selection. This example uses the method to read text from Project by specifying the coercionType parameter as CoercionType.Text. You can also use the getSelectedDataAsync method to read range (matrix) and table data in Excel or Word, specifying either of those data types as the coercionType parameter of the method. The callback function returns an object containing the data currently selected by the user, which can use the asyncResult.value property to access the selected data.

task.title: Step 2 of 3. Read task ID from user selection
task.description: Use the ProjectDocument.getSelectedTaskAsync method to retrieve the currently selected task. The return value is a GUID which uniquely identifies the task object.

task.title: Step 3 of 3. Read task data from user selection
task.description: After retrieving a task ID, use the ProjectDocument.getTaskAsync method to retrieve the data from a given task. Enter in a task ID and the return value is an object containing all of the meaninful data from that task.
